title: CVPR_2006_10_abs

sentences.text: In this paper we discuss object detection when only a small number of training examples are given .
Specifically , we show how to incorporate a simple prior on the distribution of natural images into support vector machines .
SVMs are known to be robust to overfitting ; however , a few training examples usually do not represent well the structure of the class .
Thus the resulting detectors are not robust and highly depend on the choice of the training examples .

We incorporate the prior on natural images by requiring that the separating hyperplane will not only yield a wide margin , but also that the corresponding positive half space will have a low probability to contain natural images -LRB- the background -RRB- .

Our experiments on real data sets show that the resulting detector is more robust to the choice of training examples , and substantially improves both linear and kernel SVM when trained on 10 positive and 10 negative examples .

Entity-the_resulting_detector_(1).label: the resulting detector
Entity-the_resulting_detector_(1).description: A support vector machine-based object detection model that is more robust to the choice of training examples, obtained by incorporating a prior on natural images into the SVM.

Entity-a_simple_prior_on_the_distributio.description: A probabilistic model that assumes a certain structure or pattern in the distribution of natural images, used as a constraint to improve object detection when only a small number of training examples are available.

summary: In this paper we discuss object detection when only a small number of training examples are given . Specifically , we show how to incorporate a simple prior on the distribution of natural images into support vector machines . SVMs are known to be robust to overfitting ; however , a few training examples usually do not represent well the structure of the class . Thus the resulting detectors are not robust and highly depend on the choice of the training examples . We incorporate the prior on natural images by requiring that the separating hyperplane will not only yield a wide margin , but also that the corresponding positive half space will have a low probability to contain natural images -LRB- the background -RRB- . Our experiments on real data sets show that the resulting detector is more robust to the choice of training examples , and substantially improves both linear and kernel SVM when trained on 10 positive and 10 negative examples .

Predicate-discuss.label: discuss
Predicate-discuss.description: To discuss means to engage in an exchange or conversation about something with someone, often involving consideration and exploration of ideas, perspectives, or challenges. In this context, it implies a thoughtful examination and analysis of the object (in this case, 'when only a small number of training examples are given') from different angles, potentially leading to insights, solutions, or new understandings.

Predicate-incorporate.label: incorporate
Predicate-incorporate.description: To incorporate means to integrate or combine two entities in such a way that one becomes an inherent part of the other. This predicate suggests a process where the subject (e.g., SVMs) absorbs, assimilates, or merges with another entity (the object), resulting in a new whole that reflects the characteristics and properties of both.

Predicate-are_known_to_be_robust_to.label: are known to be robust to
Predicate-are_known_to_be_robust_to.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a property or characteristic that makes it resistant or immune to the effects of the object. In other words, the subject's robustness to the object means that it can withstand or tolerate the presence of the object without being significantly impacted.

Predicate-are_not_robust_due_to_dependen.label: are not robust due to dependence on
Predicate-are_not_robust_due_to_dependen.description: This predicate indicates that a subject's property or characteristic (in this case, being 'robust') is compromised or impaired because it relies heavily on another entity or factor represented by the object. The dependence can be direct or indirect, and may involve various degrees of influence or control.

Predicate-improves_when_trained_on.label: improves when trained on
Predicate-improves_when_trained_on.description: The predicate 'improves when trained on' indicates a relationship between a subject (typically an algorithm or model) and its performance outcome, which depends on the quality and quantity of training data provided. In this context, the object represents the specific set of examples used for training, and the predicate suggests that the subject's performance improves as it is exposed to more comprehensive, diverse, or well-curated training data.

Predicate-usually_do_not_represent_well_.label: usually do not represent well the structure of the class
Predicate-usually_do_not_represent_well_.description: This predicate indicates that there is a mismatch or lack of correspondence between the subject and object in terms of representing the underlying structure or essence of a particular class. It suggests that the subject, which may be training examples, does not accurately capture the fundamental nature or characteristics of the class, resulting in an imperfect representation.

Predicate-obtained_by.label: obtained by
Predicate-obtained_by.description: Indicates a causal or generative relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject was derived from or arose as a result of the process described in the object. This predicate implies a sense of origin or provenance, highlighting how something came to be.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is a more specific instance of the object concept. It establishes a hierarchical relationship between the two, where the subject is a narrower or more specialized version of the object.
